div.p: The Life of HENRY the Second: King of England.

Shewing what troubles befell in his Raigne, concerning the warres betweene him and his Subjects, and also the manner how he set up his Standerd neere Rudland, Henry of Essex being Generall, and the manner how he left his Crowne; necessary to be observed in these dangerous and distracted times of ours.
Printed at London for H. B. 1642.

div.head: THE Life of HENRY the Second King of England, shewing what troubles befell in his Raign concerning the Warres betweene him and his Subjects, and also the manner how he set up his Standerd neare Rudland, &c.
div.p: IN the yeare of our Lord 1154. Henry the second was Crowned, he was a man of a low stature, and fat of body, of a fresh colour, a valiant Souldier, a good Scholler, and of good expression in his speech; very wise, and much delighted with peace.

In the second yeare of his Reigne a Counsell was held at Wallingford, where the Nobles were sworne to the King and his Issue, by an oath of Allegiance composed by the King and his Counsell for that purpose, after which Geffery the Kings Brother rose in Rebellion, & did much hurt, but was afterwards overcome by the King, and all was yeelded into the Kings hands.

In the third yeare of his Reigne the Welchmen rose against
him, and the King raised an Army, and made Henry of Essex his chiefe Generall of the Army; and when the King was come into Wales, Henry of Essex by the Commandement of the King raised the Standerd, and open warres was proclaimed, and many from their owne habibations (as also out of diverse prisons) came to assist the King, and there was a great battell fought neere to Rudland, where there was many men slaine on both sides, but the King recovered the Castle, and marched towards the Castle of Basingwirk, where there was a great slaughter on the Kings Army, by reason whereof the Army was much discouraged, and Henry of Essex, and those under him who had the trust of the bearing of the Standerd, did at that time let the Standerd fall downe to the ground in the battell, which did so exceedingly encourage the Welch men, that they pursued with great eagernesse; the King himselfe was exceedingly dismayed hereat, and fled to save his life, but the two Armies fought daily, for by the helpe of the Earle of Clare it was raised up againe.

Now the King had appointed a Navy of Ships also to goe forth against them and Madoc ap Merideth was Admirall of the seas, who had spoyled divers Churches, and done much hurt in the Isle of Man, and Anglesey, but after much bloud-shed they began on both sides to be weary of War, and there was an agreement and peace concluded, and on the next Christmas day after King Henry being at Worcester went to Church, and going to prayers with the Congregation tooke his Crowne off his Head, and laid it on the Communion Table, and would never weare it after.

In the seventh yeare of his Reigne there being great troubles in Ireland about the Rudiments of Faith, and Ecclesiasticall Rights, the King called a Counsell, and
Nicholas of Willingford, and William Fitz-Adelme were sent over into Ireland by the authority and consent of the King and Counsell, at which time was this Confession, or Creed published, viz.

q.p: I Beleeve in God Fadir Almichty spipper of Heaven and Earth, and in Ihesus Christ his oneleihi Son ure Loverd, that is ivange Thurch, the holy Ghost bore of Mary maiden, Tholede pine under Ponce Pilat, picht on rode Tree, dead and is buried, licht into hell, the tridde day from death arose, steich into heaven, sit on his Fadir richt honde God Almichty, then is comminde to deme the quickke and the dede, I beleeve in the holy Ghost, all holy Chirche, mone of alle hallwen, forgivenis of sine, Fleiss uprising, lif withouten end. Amen.

div.p: The King also caused an Oath of fidelity to be drawne, for his Subjects to sweare to his Son Prince Henry, concerning his Inheritance under their fidelity to the King, in case the King should dye before his Son, which Protestation was taken through the whole Kingdome.
In the 8th. yeare of his Reigne there was a Sect sprang up called Publicans, the chiefe Leader of them was one Gerard a good Scholler, but his fellowes were most of them silly and ignorant people.

list.item: The Rights and Ceremonies of the Church.

div.p: These were so stiffe, and stood so stoutly in their opinions, that they would not be convinced of any errour in their tenents, and when Gerard the chiefe of them was brought to Oxford, he would not recant from any of his tenents, wherefore judgement was denounced against them.

1. That they should be stigmatized in their foreheads, 2. That they should be whipt. 3. That they should be turned out of the City, 4. That they should not be received into any Towne. 5. That none should give them any releefe. 6. That none should afford them any succour.

These men neverthelesse suffered joyfully, singing as they went, Blessed are ye when men hate you, blessed are yee when men hate you, and so wandred in the fields till with the cold & hunger, they all dyed for no man durst releeve them.
In the 9. year of his raign, Henry of Essex was accused of high Treason before the Nobility, and these Articles were exhibited against him.
1. That the said Henry of Essex did in the expedition into Wales in narrow, and hard passage (at Colleshell) most fraudulently throw away the Kings Standerd.
2. That hee did with a loud voice pronounce the King to be dead.
3. That he turned back those that came to relive the Ks. Army against the Welchmen.

These Articles he denied, and after great debate therof before the King and his Counsell the matter was judged to be tryed by combate, and Henry of Essex supposed to be slaine was carried away, but he revived, and spent the rest of his dayes in great humility in Redding.
In the 12th yeare of his Reign the King appointed a collection to be made through all his Countreys, in this manner, viz.
1. For every pound in moveable goods being so valued for the first year, 2d.
2. For four years after for every pound so valued. 1d.
3. For Arable lands, and for vines, the charge and cost of •• em not rekoned, for every pound thereof after the same ••• ner also.
4. He that hath an house valued to be worth 1. pound, to pay one penny.
5. He that hath some office agent, one penny.

After the payment whereof, the King caused his son Henry to be crowned, by the perswasions of Robert Archbishop of Yorke, thinking it would prove to the great quietnesse of himselfe, and his Realme, but it proved otherwise, for the young King received the fealties of the Earles and Barons.

Henry the younger rebelled against his Father, and many Earles and Barons fled over to him, and many great and bloody battels were fought between them, but at the last the olde King subdued this Rebellion, and finding that the Scots had joyned against him, gave to many of the young Nobilitie, whom hee had found to bee loyall unto him, the most part of the land in Scotland, & imprisoned and fined many of the English for this Rebellion.

In the 21. year of his Reign, a brother of the Earle of Ferres was slain in the City of London; wherat the King was much displeased, and vowed revenge against the Citie; And there were great troubles between the Court & the City, insomuch that the Citie was distracted and disquie • ed within it selfe, for in the end there were many unruly Citizens who did give themselves to the pillaging and robbing of rich mens houses, of whom one Andrew Buckequint and Iohn Ould were chief, but the grave wisedome of the King soone suppressed them, and there was peace between the young King and the old, and the Father and the son did eat and drinke at one table, and all was ended in peace, and shortly after the disobedient son was cut off, and the old King Reigned quietly alone.

Then the King called a Convocation of the Clergy at
London, and the Popes Legat sate in the chare, and next to him the Arch-Bishop of Canterbury on his right hand as Primate of England; but when the Arch-Bishop of Yorke saw that hee must sit on the left hand of the Popes Legat hee disdained the place, and did strive to crowd his arse between them, but because the Legat was not to remoue, nor the Arch-bishop would not remove, therefore the most unmannerly swopt him down on the Archbishop of Canterburies lap, for which he was throw downe to the ground, and after his complaint made to the King; of whom be thought to have found reliefe but was deceived, he was well laught at for his remedy.

In the 25 year of his Reign, there was againe a rebellion after great taxes laid upon the Subjects for the voyage to Ierusalem, whereat the Kings Majestie was so perplexed and troubled, that he cursed the day wherein hee was borne, and none about him, neither Clergy nor Nobles could comfort him, through the extreamity wherof he was brought to a grievous sicknesse, after he had reigned 34 yeares, being above 60. years of age, and leaving in his treasury above 100000 markes he died.

When this royall King was carried forth to be buried, he was first aparralled in his Princely robes, & his crowne upon his head, and rich gloves on his hands, and bootes on his legs, wrought with gold spurs on his heels, a ring of gold on his finget, a Scepter in his hand, and a sword by his side, and lying thus like a Prince in State, though a dead corpes, he was uncovered, and looking upon him, under his robes, he looked with a most sweete and pleasant countenance, as if he had only slept, who was again covered, & as he deserved most honourably buried.
